chapter.title: Chapter 5 Pretty Little Girls' School: The Structure Of Lojban selbri

section.title: 1. Lojban content words: brivla
section.para: At the center, logically and often physically, of every Lojban bridi is one or more words which constitute the selbri. A bridi expresses a relationship between things: the selbri specifies which relationship is referred to. The difference between:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: do mamta mi
interlinear-gloss.gloss: You are-a-mother-of me
interlinear-gloss.en: You are my mother

section.para: and

interlinear-gloss.jbo: do patfu mi
interlinear-gloss.gloss: You are-a-father-of me.
interlinear-gloss.en: You are my father.

section.para: lies in the different selbri.

The simplest kind of selbri is a single Lojban content word: a brivla. There are three different varieties of brivla: those which are built into the language (the gismu), those which are derived from combinations of the gismu (the lujvo), and those which are taken (usually in a modified form) from other languages (the fu'ivla). In addition, there are a few cmavo that can act like brivla; these are mentioned in , and discussed in full in .
For the purposes of this chapter, however, all brivla are alike. For example,

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta bloti
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That is-a-boat.
interlinear-gloss.en: That is a boat.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta brablo
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That is-a-large-boat.
interlinear-gloss.en: That is a ship.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta blotrskunri
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That is-a-(boat)-schooner.
interlinear-gloss.en: That is a schooner.

section.para: illustrate the three types of brivla (gismu, lujvo, and fu'ivla respectively), but in each case the selbri is composed of a single word whose meaning can be learned independent of its origins.

The remainder of this chapter will mostly use gismu as example brivla, because they are short. However, it is important to keep in mind that wherever a gismu appears, it could be replaced by any other kind of brivla.

section.title: 2. Simple tanru
section.para: Beyond the single brivla, a selbri may consist of two brivla placed together. When a selbri is built in this way from more than one brivla, it is called a tanru, a word with no single English equivalent. The nearest analogue to tanru in English are combinations of two nouns such as lemon tree. There is no way to tell just by looking at the phrase lemon treeexactly what it refers to, even if you know the meanings of lemonand treeby themselves. As English-speakers, we must simply know that it refers to a tree which bears lemons as fruits. A person who didn't know English very well might think of it as analogous to brown treeand wonder, What kind of tree is lemon-colored?

In Lojban, tanru are also used for the same purposes as English adjective-noun combinations like big boyand adverb-verb combinations like quickly run. This is a consequence of Lojban not having any such categories as noun, verb, adjective, or adverb. English words belonging to any of these categories are translated by simple brivla in Lojban. Here are some examples of tanru:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: tu pelnimre tricu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That-yonder is-a-(lemon tree).
interlinear-gloss.en: That is a lemon tree.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la djan. barda nanla
interlinear-gloss.gloss: John is-a-big boy.
interlinear-gloss.en: John is a big boy.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi sutra bajra
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I quick run.
interlinear-gloss.en: I quickly run/I run quickly.

section.para: Note that pelnimreis a lujvo for lemon; it is derived from the gismu pelxu, yellow, and nimre, citrus. Note also that sutracan mean fast/quickor quicklydepending on its use:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi sutra
interlinear-gloss.en: I am-fast/quick.

section.para: shows sutraused to translate an adjective, whereas in it is translating an adverb. (Another correct translation of , however, would be I am a quick runner.)

There are special Lojban terms for the two components of a tanru, derived from the place structure of the word tanru. The first component is called the seltau, and the second component is called the tertau.

The most important rule for use in interpreting tanru is that the tertau carries the primary meaning. A pelnimre tricuis primarily a tree, and only secondarily is it connected with lemons in some way. For this reason, an alternative translation of would be:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: That is a lemon type of tree.

section.para: This type ofrelationship between the components of a tanru is fundamental to the tanru concept.
We may also say that the seltau modifies the meaning of the tertau:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: That is a tree which is lemon-ish (in the way appropriate to trees)

section.para: would be another possible translation of . In the same way, a more explicit translation of might be:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: John is a boy who is big in the way that boys are big.

section.para: This way that boys are bigwould be quite different from the way in which elephants are big; big-for-a-boy is small-for-an-elephant.
All tanru are ambiguous semantically. Possible translations of:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta klama jubme
interlinear-gloss.en: That is-a-goer type-of-table.

section.para: include:
section.programlisting: That is a table which goes (a wheeled table, perhaps). That is a table owned by one who goes. That is a table used by those who go (a sports doctor's table?). That is a table when it goes (otherwise it is a chair?).
section.para: In each case the object referred to is a goer type of table, but the ambiguous type ofrelationship can mean one of many things. A speaker who uses tanru (and pragmatically all speakers must) takes the risk of being misunderstood. Using tanru is convenient because they are short and expressive; the circumlocution required to squeeze out all ambiguity can require too much effort.
No general theory covering the meaning of all possible tanru exists; probably no such theory can exist. However, some regularities obviously do exist:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: do barda prenu
interlinear-gloss.en: You are-a-large person.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: do cmalu prenu
interlinear-gloss.en: You are-a-small person.

section.para: are parallel tanru, in the sense that the relationship between bardaand prenuis the same as that between cmaluand prenu. and contain a partial listing of some types of tanru, with examples.

section.title: 3. Three-part tanru grouping with bo
section.para: The following cmavo is discussed in this section:
Consider the English sentence:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: That's a little girls' school.

section.para: What does it mean? Two possible readings are:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: That's a little school for girls.
That's a school for little girls.

section.para: This ambiguity is quite different from the simple tanru ambiguity described in . We understand that girls' schoolmeans a school where girls are the students, and not a school where girls are the teachersor a school which is a girl(!). Likewise, we understand that little girlmeans girl who is small. This is an ambiguity of grouping. Is girls' schoolto be taken as a unit, with littlespecifying the type of girls' school? Or is little girlto be taken as a unit, specifying the type of school? In English speech, different tones of voice, or exaggerated speech rhythm showing the grouping, are used to make the distinction; English writing usually leaves it unrepresented.

Lojban makes no use of tones of voice for any purpose; explicit words are used to do the work. The cmavo bo(which belongs to selma'o BO) may be placed between the two brivla which are most closely associated. Therefore, a Lojban translation of would be:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta cmalu nixli bo ckule
interlinear-gloss.en: That is-a-small girl – school.

section.para: might be translated:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta cmalu bo nixli ckule
interlinear-gloss.en: That is-a-small – girl school.

section.para: The bois represented in the literal translation by a hyphen because in written English a hyphen is sometimes used for the same purpose: a big dog-catcherwould be quite different from a big-dog catcher(presumably someone who catches only big dogs).

Analysis of and reveals a tanru nested within a tanru. In , the main tanru has a seltau of cmaluand a tertau of nixli bo ckule; the tertau is itself a tanru with nixlias the seltau and ckuleas the tertau. In , on the other hand, the seltau is cmalu bo nixli(itself a tanru), whereas the tertau is ckule. This structure of tanru nested within tanru forms the basis for all the more complex types of selbri that will be explained below.
What about ? What does it mean?

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta cmalu nixli ckule
interlinear-gloss.en: That is-a-small girl school.

section.para: The rules of Lojban do not leave this sentence ambiguous, as the rules of English do with . The choice made by the language designers is to say that means the same as . This is true no matter what three brivla are used: the leftmost two are always grouped together. This rule is called the left-grouping rule. Left-grouping in seemingly ambiguous structures is quite common - though not universal - in other contexts in Lojban.
Another way to express the English meaning of and , using parentheses to mark grouping, is:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta cmalu nixli bo ckule
interlinear-gloss.en: That is-a-small type-of (girl type-of school).
interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta cmalu bo nixli ckule
interlinear-gloss.en: That is-a-(small type-of girl) type-of school.

section.para: Because type-ofis implicit in the Lojban tanru form, it has no Lojban equivalent.
Note: It is perfectly legal, though pointless, to insert bointo a simple tanru:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta klama bo jubme
interlinear-gloss.en: That is-a goer–table.

section.para: is a legal Lojban bridi that means exactly the same thing as , and is ambiguous in exactly the same ways. The cmavo boserves only to resolve grouping ambiguity: it says nothing about the more basic ambiguity present in all tanru.

section.title: 4. Complex tanru grouping
section.para: If one element of a tanru can be another tanru, why not both elements?

interlinear-gloss.jbo: do mutce bo barda gerku bo kavbu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: You are-a-(very type-of large) (dog type-of capturer).
interlinear-gloss.en: You are a very large dog-catcher.

section.para: In , the selbri is a tanru with seltau mutce bo bardaand tertau gerku bo kavbu. It is worth emphasizing once again that this tanru has the same fundamental ambiguity as all other Lojban tanru: the sense in which the dog type-of captureris said to be very type-of largeis not precisely specified. Presumably it is his body which is large, but theoretically it could be one of his other properties.

We will now justify the title of this chapter by exploring the ramifications of the phrase pretty little girls' school, an expansion of the tanru used in to four brivla. (Although this example has been used in the Loglan Project almost since the beginning - it first appeared in Quine's book Word and Object(1960) - it is actually a mediocre example because of the ambiguity of English pretty; it can mean beautiful, the sense intended here, or it can mean very. Lojban melbiis not subject to this ambiguity: it means only beautiful.)
Here are four ways to group this phrase:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta melbi cmalu nixli ckule
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That is-a-((pretty type-of little) type-of girl) type-of school.
interlinear-gloss.en: That is a school for girls who are beautifully small.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta melbi cmalu nixli bo ckule
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That is-a-(pretty type-of little) (girl type-of school).
interlinear-gloss.en: That is a girls' school which is beautifully small.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta melbi cmalu bo nixli ckule
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That is-a-(pretty type-of (little type-of girl)) type-of school.
interlinear-gloss.en: That is a school for small girls who are beautiful.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta melbi cmalu bo nixli bo ckule
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That is-a-pretty type-of (little type-of (girl type-of school)).
interlinear-gloss.en: That is a small school for girls which is beautiful.

section.para: uses a construction which has not been seen before: cmalu bo nixli bo ckule, with two consecutive uses of bobetween brivla. The rule for multiple boconstructions is the opposite of the rule when no bois present at all: the last two are grouped together. Not surprisingly, this is called the right-grouping rule, and it is associated with every use of boin the language. Therefore,

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta cmalu bo nixli bo ckule
interlinear-gloss.en: That is-a-little type-of (girl type-of school).

section.para: means the same as , not . This rule may seem peculiar at first, but one of its consequences is that bois never necessary between the first two elements of any of the complex tanru presented so far: all of through could have boinserted between melbiand cmaluwith no change in meaning.

section.title: 5. Complex tanru with keand ke'e
section.para: The following cmavo are discussed in this section:

There is, in fact, a fifth grouping of pretty little girls' schoolthat cannot be expressed with the resources explained so far. To handle it, we must introduce the grouping parentheses cmavo, keand ke'e(belonging to selma'o KE and KEhE respectively). Any portion of a selbri sandwiched between these two cmavo is taken to be a single tanru component, independently of what is adjacent to it. Thus, can be rewritten in any of the following ways:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta ke melbi cmalu ke'e nixli ckule
interlinear-gloss.en: That is-a-( pretty little ) girl school.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta ke ke melbi cmalu ke'e nixli ke'e ckule
interlinear-gloss.en: That is-a-( ( pretty little ) girl ) school.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta ke ke ke melbi cmalu ke'e nixli ke'e ckule ke'e
interlinear-gloss.en: That is-a-( ( ( pretty little ) girl ) school ).

section.para: Even more versions could be created simply by placing any number of kecmavo at the beginning of the selbri, and a like number of ke'ecmavo at its end. Obviously, all of these are a waste of breath once the left-grouping rule has been grasped. However, the following is equivalent to and may be easier to understand:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta melbi ke cmalu nixli ke'e ckule
interlinear-gloss.en: That is-a-( pretty type-of ( little type-of girl ) ) type-of school.

section.para: Likewise, a keand ke'eversion of would be:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta melbi cmalu ke nixli ckule [ke'e]
interlinear-gloss.en: That is-a-(pretty type-of little) ( girl type-of school ).

section.para: The final ke'eis given in square brackets here to indicate that it can be elided. It is always possible to elide ke'eat the end of the selbri, making as terse as .
Now how about that fifth grouping? It is

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta melbi ke cmalu nixli ckule [ke'e]
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That is-a-pretty type-of ( ( little type-of girl ) type-of school ).
interlinear-gloss.en: That is a beautiful school for small girls.

section.para: is distinctly different in meaning from any of Examples 4.2 through 4.5. Note that within the ke ... ke'eparentheses, the left-grouping rule is applied to cmalu nixli ckule.
It is perfectly all right to mix boand ke ... ke'ein a single selbri. For instance, , which in pure ke ... ke'eform is

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta melbi ke cmalu ke nixli ckule [ke'e] [ke'e]
interlinear-gloss.en: That is-a-pretty type-of ( little type-of ( girl type-of school ) ).

section.para: can equivalently be expressed as:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta melbi ke cmalu nixli bo ckule [ke'e]
interlinear-gloss.en: That is-a-pretty type-of ( little type-of ( girl type-of school ) ).

section.para: and in many other different forms as well.

section.title: 6. Logical connection within tanru
section.para: The following cmavo are discussed in this section:
section.programlisting: je JA tanru logical and ja JA tanru logical or joi JOI mixed mass and gu'e GUhA tanru forethought logical and gi GI forethought connection separator
section.para: Consider the English phrase big red dog. How shall this be rendered as a Lojban tanru? The naive attempt:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: barda xunre gerku
interlinear-gloss.en: (big type-of red) type-of dog

section.para: will not do, as it means a dog whose redness is big, in whatever way redness might be described as big. Nor is

interlinear-gloss.jbo: barda xunre bo gerku
interlinear-gloss.en: big type-of (red type-of dog)

section.para: much better. After all, the straightforward understanding of the English phrase is that the dog is big as compared with other dogs, not merely as compared with other red dogs. In fact, the bigness and redness are independent properties of the dog, and only obscure rules of English adjective ordering prevent us from saying red big dog.
The Lojban approach to this problem is to introduce the cmavo je, which is one of the many equivalents of English and. A big red dog is one that is both big and red, and we can say:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: barda je xunre gerku
interlinear-gloss.en: (big and red) type-of dog

section.para: Of course,

interlinear-gloss.jbo: xunre je barda gerku
interlinear-gloss.en: (red and big) type-of dog

section.para: is equally satisfactory and means the same thing. As these examples indicate, joining two brivla with jemakes them a unit for tanru purposes. However, explicit grouping with boor ke ... ke'eassociates brivla more closely than jedoes:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: barda je pelxu bo xunre gerku
interlinear-gloss.gloss: barda je ke pelxu xunre ke'e gerku
(big and (yellow type-of red)) dog
interlinear-gloss.en: big yellowish-red dog

section.para: With no grouping indicators, we get:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: barda je pelxu xunre gerku
interlinear-gloss.gloss: ((big and yellow) type-of red) type-of dog
interlinear-gloss.en: biggish- and yellowish-red dog

section.para: which again raises the question of : what does biggish-redmean?
Unlike boand ke ... ke'e, jeis useful as well as merely legal within simple tanru. It may be used to partly resolve the ambiguity of simple tanru:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta blanu je zdani
interlinear-gloss.en: that is-blue and is-a-house

section.para: definitely refers to something which is both blue and is a house, and not to any of the other possible interpretations of simple blanu zdani. Furthermore, blanu zdanirefers to something which is blue in the way that houses are blue; blanu je zdanihas no such implication - the blueness of a blanu je zdaniis independent of its houseness.
With the addition of je, many more versions of pretty little girls' schoolare made possible: see for a complete list.
A subtle point in the semantics of tanru like needs special elucidation. There are at least two possible interpretations of:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta melbi je nixli ckule
interlinear-gloss.en: That is-a-(beautiful and girl) type-of school.

section.para: It can be understood as:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: That is a girls' school and a beautiful school.

section.para: or as:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: That is a school for things which are both girls and beautiful.

section.para: The interpretation specified by treats the tanru as a sort of abbreviation for:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta ke melbi ckule ke'e je ke nixli ckule [ke'e]
interlinear-gloss.en: That is-a-( beautiful type-of school ) and ( girl type-of school )

section.para: whereas the interpretation specified by does not. This is a kind of semantic ambiguity for which Lojban does not compel a firm resolution. The way in which the school is said to be of type beautiful and girlmay entail that it is separately a beautiful school and a girls' school; but the alternative interpretation, that the members of the school are beautiful and girls, is also possible. Still another interpretation is:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: That is a school for beautiful things and also for girls.

section.para: so while the logical connectives help to resolve the meaning of tanru, they by no means compel a single meaning in and of themselves.
In general, logical connectives within tanru cannot undergo the formal manipulations that are possible with the related logical connectives that exist outside tanru; see for further details.
The logical connective jeis only one of the fourteen logical connectives that Lojban provides. Here are a few examples of some of the others:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le bajra cu jinga ja te jinga
interlinear-gloss.en: the runner(s) is/are winner(s) or loser(s).
interlinear-gloss.jbo: blanu naja lenku skapi
interlinear-gloss.gloss: (blue only-if cold) skin
interlinear-gloss.en: skin which is blue only if it is cold
interlinear-gloss.jbo: xamgu jo cortu nuntavla
interlinear-gloss.gloss: (good if-and-only-if short) speech
interlinear-gloss.en: speech which is good if (and only if) it is short
interlinear-gloss.jbo: vajni ju pluka nuntavla
interlinear-gloss.gloss: (important whether-or-not pleasing) event-of-talking
interlinear-gloss.en: speech which is important, whether or not it is pleasing

section.para: In , jais grammatically equivalent to jebut means or(more precisely, and/or). Likewise, najameans only ifin , jomeans if and only ifin , and jumeans whether or notin .
Now consider the following example:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ricfu je blanu jabo crino
interlinear-gloss.en: rich and (blue or green)

section.para: which illustrates a new grammatical feature: the use of both jaand bobetween tanru components. The two cmavo combine to form a compound whose meaning is that of jabut which groups more closely; jabois to jaas plain bois to no cmavo at all. However, both jaand jabogroup less closely than bodoes:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ricfu je blanu jabo crino bo blanu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: rich and (blue or green – blue)
interlinear-gloss.en: rich and (blue or greenish-blue)

section.para: An alternative form of is:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ricfu je ke blanu ja crino [ke'e]
interlinear-gloss.en: rich and (blue or green)

section.para: In addition to the logical connectives, there are also a variety of non-logical connectives, grammatically equivalent to the logical ones. The only one with a well-understood meaning in tanru contexts is joi, which is the kind of andthat denotes a mixture:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ti blanu joi xunre bolci
interlinear-gloss.en: This is-a-(blue and red) ball.

section.para: The ball described is neither solely red nor solely blue, but probably striped or in some other way exhibiting a combination of the two colors. is distinct from:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ti blanu xunre bolci
interlinear-gloss.en: This is a bluish-red ball

section.para: which would be a ball whose color is some sort of purple tending toward red, since xunreis the more important of the two components. On the other hand,

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ti blanu je xunre bolci
interlinear-gloss.en: This is a (blue and red) ball

section.para: is probably self-contradictory, seeming to claim that the ball is independently both blue and red at the same time, although some sensible interpretation may exist.
Finally, just as English andhas the variant form both ... and, so jebetween tanru components has the variant form gu'e ... gi, where gu'eis placed before the components and gibetween them:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: gu'e barda gi xunre gerku
interlinear-gloss.en: (both big and red) type-of dog

section.para: is equivalent in meaning to . For each logical connective related to je, there is a corresponding connective related to gu'e ... giin a systematic way.

The portion of a gu'e ... giconstruction before the giis a full selbri, and may use any of the selbri resources including jelogical connections. After the gi, logical connections are taken to be wider in scope than the gu'e ... gi, which has in effect the same scope as bo:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: gu'e barda je xunre gi gerku ja mlatu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: (both (big and red) and dog) or cat
interlinear-gloss.en: something which is either big, red, and a dog, or else a cat

section.para: leaves mlatuoutside the gu'e ... giconstruction. The scope of the giarm extends only to a single brivla or to two or more brivla connected with boor ke ... ke'e.

section.title: 7. Linked sumti: be–bei–be'o
section.para: The following cmavo are discussed in this section:

The question of the place structures of selbri has been glossed over so far. This chapter does not attempt to treat place structure issues in detail; they are discussed in . One grammatical structure related to places belongs here, however. In simple sentences such as , the place structure of the selbri is simply the defined place structure of the gismu mamta. What about more complex selbri?

For tanru, the place structure rule is simple: the place structure of a tanru is always the place structure of its tertau. Thus, the place structure of blanu zdaniis that of zdani: the x1 place is a house or nest, and the x2 place is its occupants.

What about the places of blanu? Is there any way to get them into the act? In fact, blanuhas only one place, and this is merged, as it were, with the x1 place of zdani. It is whatever is in the x1 place that is being characterized as blue-for-a-house. But if we replace blanuwith xamgu, we get:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ti xamgu zdani
interlinear-gloss.gloss: This is-a-good house.
interlinear-gloss.en: This is a good (for someone, by some standard) house.

section.para: Since xamguhas three places (x1, the good thing; x2, the person for whom it is good; and x3, the standard of goodness), necessarily omits information about the last two: there is no room for them. Room can be made, however!

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ti xamgu be do bei mi [be'o] zdani
interlinear-gloss.gloss: This is-a-good (for you by-standard me) house.
interlinear-gloss.en: This is a house that is good for you by my standards.

section.para: Here, the gismu xamguhas been followed by the cmavo be(of selma'o BE), which signals that one or more sumti follows. These sumti are not part of the overall bridi place structure, but fill the places of the brivla they are attached to, starting with x2. If there is more than one sumti, they are separated by the cmavo bei(of selma'o BEI), and the list of sumti is terminated by the elidable terminator be'o(of selma'o BEhO).
Grammatically, a brivla with sumti linked to it in this fashion plays the same role in tanru as a simple brivla. To illustrate, here is a fully fleshed-out version of , with all places filled in:

section.para: Here the three places of cmalu, the three of nixli, and the four of ckuleare fully specified. Since the places of ckuleare the places of the bridi as a whole, it was not necessary to link the sumti which follow ckule. It would have been legal to do so, however:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi klama be le zarci bei le zdani [be'o]
interlinear-gloss.en: I go (to-the market from-the house).

section.para: means the same as

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi klama le zarci le zdani
interlinear-gloss.en: I go to-the market from-the house.

section.para: No matter how complex a tanru gets, the last brivla always dictates the place structure: the place structure of

interlinear-gloss.jbo: melbi je cmalu nixli bo ckule
interlinear-gloss.gloss: a (pretty and little) (girl school)
interlinear-gloss.en: a school for girls which is both beautiful and small

section.para: is simply that of ckule. (The sole exception to this rule is discussed in .)

It is possible to precede linked sumti by the place structure ordering tags fe, fi, fo, and fu(of selma'o FA, discussed further in ), which serve to explicitly specify the x2, x3, x4, and x5 places respectively. Normally, the place following the beis the x2 place and the other places follow in order. If it seems convenient to change the order, however, it can be accomplished as follows:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ti xamgu be fi mi bei fe do [be'o] zdani
interlinear-gloss.en: This is-a-good ( by-standard me for you ) house.

section.para: which is equivalent in meaning to . Note that the order of be, bei, and be'odoes not change; only the inserted fitells us that miis the x3 place (and correspondingly, the inserted fetells us that dois the x2 place). Changing the order of sumti is often done to match the order of another language, or for emphasis or rhythm.
Of course, using FA cmavo makes it easy to specify one place while omitting a previous place:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ti xamgu be fi mi [be'o] zdani
interlinear-gloss.gloss: This is-a-good (by-standard me) house.
interlinear-gloss.en: This is a good house by my standards.

section.para: Similarly, sumti labeled by modal or tense tags can be inserted into strings of linked sumti just as they can into bridi:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta blanu be ga'a mi [be'o] zdani
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That is-a-blue (to-observer me) house.
interlinear-gloss.en: That is a blue, as I see it, house.

section.para: The meaning of is slightly different from:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta blanu zdani ga'a mi
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That is-a-blue house to-observer me.
interlinear-gloss.en: That is a blue house, as I see it.

section.para: See discussions in of modals and in of tenses for more explanations.

The terminator be'ois almost always elidable: however, if the selbri belongs to a description, then a relative clause following it will attach to the last linked sumti unless be'ois used, in which case it will attach to the outer description:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le xamgu be do noi barda cu zdani
interlinear-gloss.en: The good-thing for you (who are-large) is-a-house.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: le xamgu be do be'o noi barda cu zdani
interlinear-gloss.en: The (good-thing for you) (which is-large) is-a-house

section.para: (Relative clauses are explained in .)
In other cases, however, be'ocannot be elided if kuhas also been elided:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le xamgu be le ctuca [ku] be'o zdani
interlinear-gloss.en: the good (for the teacher) house

section.para: requires either kuor be'o, and since there is only one occurrence of be, the be'omust match it, whereas it may be confusing which occurrence of lethe kuterminates (in fact the second one is correct).

section.title: 8. Inversion of tanru: co
section.para: The following cmavo is discussed in this section:

The standard order of Lojban tanru, whereby the modifier precedes what it modifies, is very natural to English-speakers: we talk of blue houses, not of houses blue. In other languages, however, such matters are differently arranged, and Lojban supports this reverse order (tertau before seltau) by inserting the particle co. and mean exactly the same thing:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta blanu zdani
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That is-a-blue type-of-house.
interlinear-gloss.en: That is a blue house.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta zdani co blanu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That is-a-house of-type blue.
interlinear-gloss.en: That is a blue house.

section.para: This change is called tanru inversion. In tanru inversion, the element before co( zdaniin ) is the tertau, and the element following co( blanu) in ) is the seltau.

The meaning, and more specifically, the place structure, of a tanru is not affected by inversion: the place structure of zdani co blanuis still that of zdani. However, the existence of inversion in a selbri has a very special effect on any sumti which follow that selbri. Instead of being interpreted as filling places of the selbri, they actually fill the places (starting with x2) of the seltau. In , we saw how to fill interior places with be ... bei ... be'o, and in fact and have the same meaning:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi klama be le zarci bei le zdani be'o troci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I am-a-(goer to the market from the house) type-of trier.
interlinear-gloss.en: I try to go to the market from the house.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi troci co klama le zarci le zdani
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I am-a-trier of-type (goer to-the market from-the house).
interlinear-gloss.en: I try to go to the market from the house.

section.para: is a less deeply nested construction, requiring fewer cmavo. As a result it is probably easier to understand.

Note that in Lojban trying to gois expressed using trocias the tertau. The reason is that trying to gois a going type of trying, not a trying type of going. The trying is more fundamental than the going - if the trying fails, we may not have a going at all.

Any sumti which precede a selbri with an inverted tanru fill the places of the selbri (i.e., the places of the tertau) in the ordinary way. In , mifills the x1 place of troci co klama, which is the x1 place of troci. The other places of the selbri remain unfilled. The trailing sumti le zarciand le zdanido not occupy selbri places, despite appearances.

As a result, the regular mechanisms (involving selma'o VOhA and GOhI, explained in ) for referring to individual sumti of a bridi cannot refer to any of the trailing places of , because they are not really sumti of the bridiat all.
When inverting a more complex tanru, it is possible to invert it only at the most general modifier-modified pair. The only possible inversion of , for instance, is:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta nixli [bo] ckule co cmalu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That (is-a-girl type-of school) of-type little.
interlinear-gloss.en: That's a girls' school which is small.

section.para: Note that the boof is optional in , because cogroups more loosely than any other cmavo used in tanru, including none at all. Not even ke ... ke'eparentheses can encompass a co:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta cmalu ke nixli ckule [ke'e] co melbi
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That is-a-(little type-of (girl type-of school)) of-type pretty.
interlinear-gloss.en: That's a small school for girls which is beautiful.

section.para: In , the ke'eis automatically inserted before the corather than at its usual place at the end of the selbri. As a result, there is a simple and mechanical rule for removing cofrom any selbri: change A co Bto ke B ke'e A. (At the same time, any sumti following the selbri must be transformed into be ... bei ... be'oform and attached following B.) Therefore,

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ckule co melbi nixli
interlinear-gloss.gloss: school of-type pretty girl
interlinear-gloss.en: school for beautiful girls

section.para: means the same as:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ke melbi nixli ke'e ckule
interlinear-gloss.en: (pretty girl) school

section.para: Multiple cocmavo can appear within a selbri, indicating multiple inversions: a right-grouping rule is employed, as for bo. The above rule can be applied to interpret such selbri, but all cocmavo must be removed simultaneously:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ckule co nixli co cmalu
interlinear-gloss.en: school of-type (girl of-type little)

section.para: becomes formally

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ke ke cmalu ke'e nixli ke'e ckule
interlinear-gloss.en: ( (little) girl ) school

section.para: which by the left-grouping rule is simply

interlinear-gloss.jbo: cmalu nixli ckule
interlinear-gloss.gloss: little girl school
interlinear-gloss.en: school for little girls

section.para: As stated above, the selbri places, other than the first, of

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi klama co sutra
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I am-a-goer of-type quick
interlinear-gloss.en: I go quickly

section.para: cannot be filled by placing sumti after the selbri, because any sumti in that position fill the places of sutra, the seltau. However, the tertau places (which means in effect the selbri places) can be filled with be:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi klama be le zarci be'o co sutra
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I am-a-goer (to the store) of-type quick.
interlinear-gloss.en: I go to the store quickly.

section.title: 9. Other kinds of simple selbri
section.para: The following cmavo are discussed in this section:

So far we have only discussed brivla and tanru built up from brivla as possible selbri. In fact, there are a few other constructions in Lojban which are grammatically equivalent to brivla: they can be used either directly as selbri, or as components in tanru. Some of these types of simple selbri are discussed at length in , , and ; but for completeness these types are mentioned here with a brief explanation and an example of their use in selbri.

The cmavo of selma'o GOhA (with one exception) serve as pro-bridi, providing a reference to the content of other bridi; none of them has a fixed meaning. The most commonly used member of GOhA is probably go'i, which amounts to a repetition of the previous bridi, or part of it. If I say:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la djan. klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.en: John goes-to the market.

section.para: you may retort:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la djan. go'i troci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: John [repeat last] are-a-tryer
interlinear-gloss.en: John tries to.

section.para: is short for:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la djan. klama be le zarci be'o troci
interlinear-gloss.en: John is-a-goer (to the market) type-of trier.

section.para: because the whole bridi of has been packaged up into the single word go'iand inserted into .
The exceptional member of GOhA is du, which represents the relation of identity. Its place structure is:
section.programlisting: x1 is identical with x2, x3, ...
section.para: for as many places as are given. More information on selma'o GOhA is available in .

Lojban mathematical expressions (mekso) can be incorporated into selbri in two different ways. Mathematical operators such as su'i, meaning plus, can be transformed into selbri by prefixing them with nu'a(of selma'o NUhA). The resulting place structure is:
section.programlisting: x1 is the result of applying (the operator) to arguments x2, x3, etc.
section.para: for as many arguments as are required. (The result goes in the x1 place because the number of following places may be indefinite.) For example:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li vo nu'a su'i li re li re
interlinear-gloss.en: The-number 4 is-the-sum-of the-number 2 and-the-number 2.

section.para: A possible tanru example might be:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi jimpe tu'a loi nu'a su'i nabmi
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I understand something-about the-mass-of is-the-sum-of problems.
interlinear-gloss.en: I understand addition problems.

section.para: More usefully, it is possible to combine a mathematical expression with a cmavo of selma'o MOI to create one of various numerical selbri. Details are available in . Here are a few tanru:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la prim. palvr. pamoi cusku
interlinear-gloss.gloss: Preem Palver is-the-1-th speaker.
interlinear-gloss.en: Preem Palver is the first speaker.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: la an,iis. joi la .asun. bruna remei
interlinear-gloss.gloss: Anyi massed-with Asun are-a-brother type-of-twosome.
interlinear-gloss.en: Anyi and Asun are two brothers.

section.para: Finally, an important type of simple selbri which is not a brivla is the abstraction. Grammatically, abstractions are simple: a cmavo of selma'o NU, followed by a bridi, followed by the elidable terminator keiof selma'o KEI. Semantically, abstractions are an extremely subtle and powerful feature of Lojban whose full ramifications are documented in . A few examples:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ti nu zdile kei kumfa
interlinear-gloss.gloss: This is-an-event-of amusement room.
interlinear-gloss.en: This is an amusement room.

section.para: is quite distinct in meaning from:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ti zdile kumfa
interlinear-gloss.en: This is-an-amuser room.

section.para: which suggests the meaning a room that amuses someone.

section.title: 10. selbri based on sumti: me
section.para: The following cmavo are discussed in this section:
section.programlisting: me ME changes sumti to simple selbri me'u MEhU terminator for me
section.para: A sumti can be made into a simple selbri by preceding it with me(of selma'o ME) and following it with the elidable terminator me'u(of selma'o MEhU). This makes a selbri with the place structure
section.programlisting: x1 is one of the referents of [the sumti]
section.para: which is true of the thing, or things, that are the referents of the sumti, and not of anything else. For example, consider the sumti

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le ci nolraitru
interlinear-gloss.gloss: the three noblest-governors
interlinear-gloss.en: the three kings

section.para: If these are understood to be the Three Kings of Christian tradition, who arrive every year on January 6, then we may say:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la BALtazar. cu me le ci nolraitru
interlinear-gloss.gloss: Balthazar is one-of-the-referents-of the three kings.
interlinear-gloss.en: Balthazar is one of the three kings.

section.para: and likewise

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la kaspar. cu me le ci nolraitru
interlinear-gloss.en: Caspar is one of the three kings.

section.para: and

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la melxi,or. cu me le ci nolraitru
interlinear-gloss.en: Melchior is one of the three kings.

section.para: If the sumti refers to a single object, then the effect of meis much like that of du:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: do du la djan.
interlinear-gloss.gloss: You are-identical-with the-one-called John.
interlinear-gloss.en: You are John.

section.para: means the same as

interlinear-gloss.jbo: do me la djan.
interlinear-gloss.gloss: You are-the-referent-of the-one-called ‘John'.
interlinear-gloss.en: You are John.

section.para: It is common to use meselbri, especially those based on name sumti using la, as seltau. For example:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta me lai kraislr. [me'u] karce
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That (is-a-referent of the-mass-called ‘Chrysler') car.
interlinear-gloss.en: That is a Chrysler car.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: re me le ci nolraitru .e la djan. [me'u] cu blabi
interlinear-gloss.en: Two of the group the three kings and Johnare white.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: re me le ci nolraitru me'u .e la djan. cu blabi
interlinear-gloss.en: Two of the three kings, and John, are white.

section.para: In the meselbri covers the three kings plus John, and the indefinite description picks out two of them that are said to be white: we cannot say which two. In , though, the meselbri covers only the three kings: two of them are said to be white, and so is John.
Finally, here is another example requiring me'u:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta me la'e le se cusku be do me'u cukta
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That is-a-(what-you-said) type of book.
interlinear-gloss.en: That is the kind of book you were talking about.

section.para: There are other sentences where either me'uor some other elidable terminator must be expressed:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le me le ci nolraitru [ku] me'u nunsalci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: the (the three kings) type-of-event-of-celebrating
interlinear-gloss.en: the Three Kings celebration

section.para: requires either kuor me'uto be explicit, and (as with be'oin ) the me'uleaves no doubt which cmavo it is paired with.

section.title: 11. Conversion of simple selbri
section.para: Conversion is the process of changing a selbri so that its places appear in a different order. This is not the same as labeling the sumti with the cmavo of FA, as mentioned in , and then rearranging the order in which the sumti are spoken or written. Conversion transforms the selbri into a distinct, though closely related, selbri with renumbered places.
In Lojban, conversion is accomplished by placing a cmavo of selma'o SE before the selbri:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi prami do
interlinear-gloss.en: I love you.

section.para: is equivalent in meaning to:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: do se prami mi
interlinear-gloss.gloss: You [swap x1 and x2] love me.
interlinear-gloss.en: You are loved by me.

section.para: Conversion is fully explained in . For the purposes of this chapter, the important point about conversion is that it applies only to the following simple selbri. When trying to convert a tanru, therefore, it is necessary to be careful! Consider :

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la .alis. cu cadzu klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: Alice is-a-walker type-of goer to-the market.
Alice walkingly goes to the market.
interlinear-gloss.en: Alice walks to the market.

section.para: To convert this sentence so that le zarciis in the x1 place, one correct way is:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le zarci cu se ke cadzu klama [ke'e] la .alis.
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The market is-a-[swap x1/x2] (walker type-of goer) Alice.
interlinear-gloss.en: The market is-walkingly gone-to by-Alice.

section.para: The ke ... ke'ebrackets cause the entire tanru to be converted by the se, which would otherwise convert only cadzu, leading to:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le zarci cu se cadzu klama la .alis.
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The market (is-a-[swap x1/x2] walker) type-of goer to Alice.
interlinear-gloss.en: The market is-a-walking-surface type-of goer to Alice.

section.para: whatever that might mean. An alternative approach, since the place structure of cadzu klamais that of klamaalone, is to convert only the latter:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le zarci cu cadzu se klama la .alis.
interlinear-gloss.en: The market walkingly is-gone-to by-Alice.

section.para: But the tanru in may or may not have the same meaning as that in ; in particular, because cadzuis not converted, there is a suggestion that although Alice is the goer, the market is the walker. With a different sumti as x1, this seemingly odd interpretation might make considerable sense:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la djan. cu cadzu se klama la .alis
interlinear-gloss.en: John walkingly is-gone-to by Alice

section.para: suggests that Alice is going to John, who is a moving target.

There is an alternative type of conversion, using the cmavo jaiof selma'o JAI optionally followed by a modal or tense construction. Grammatically, such a combination behaves exactly like conversion using SE. More details can be found in .

section.title: 12. Scalar negation of selbri
section.para: Negation is too large and complex a topic to explain fully in this chapter; see . In brief, there are two main types of negation in Lojban. This section is concerned with so-called scalar negation, which is used to state that a true relation between the sumti is something other than what the selbri specifies. Scalar negation is expressed by cmavo of selma'o NAhE:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la .alis. cu na'e ke cadzu klama [ke'e] le zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: Alice non- (walkingly goes) to-the market.
Alice other-than (walkingly goes) to-the market.
interlinear-gloss.en: Alice doesn't walk to the market.

section.para: meaning that Alice's relationship to the market is something other than that of walking there. But if the kewere omitted, the result would be:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la .alis. cu na'e cadzu klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: Alice non- walkingly goes to-the market.
interlinear-gloss.en: Alice doesn't walk to the market.

section.para: meaning that Alice does go there in some way ( klamais not negated), but by a means other than that of walking. negates both cadzuand klama, suggesting that Alice's relation to the market is something different from walkingly-going; it might be walking without going, or going without walking, or neither.
Of course, any of the simple selbri types explained in may be used in place of brivla in any of these examples:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la djonz. cu na'e pamoi cusku
interlinear-gloss.gloss: Jones is non-1st speaker
interlinear-gloss.en: Jones is not the first speaker.

section.para: Since only pamoiis negated, an appropriate inference is that he is some other kind of speaker.
Here is an assortment of more complex examples showing the interaction of scalar negation with bogrouping, keand ke'egrouping, logical connection, and sumti linked with beand bei:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi na'e sutra cadzu be fi le birka be'o klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I ( (non-quickly) ( walking using the arms) ) go-to the market.
interlinear-gloss.en: I go to the market, walking using my arms other than quickly.

section.para: In , na'enegates only sutra. Contrast :

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi na'e ke sutra cadzu be fi le birka [be'o] ke'e klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I non- ( quickly (walking using the arms) ) go-to the market.
interlinear-gloss.en: I go to the market, other than by walking quickly on my arms.

section.para: Now consider and , which are equivalent in meaning, but use kegrouping and bogrouping respectively:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi sutra cadzu be fi le birka be'o je masno klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I (quickly – (walking using the arms) and slowly) go-to the market.
interlinear-gloss.en: I go to the market, both quickly walking using my arms and slowly.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi ke sutra cadzu be fi le birka [be'o] ke'e je masno klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I ( (quickly (walking using the arms) ) and slowly) go-to the market.
interlinear-gloss.en: I go to the market, both quickly walking using my arms and slowly.

section.para: However, if we place a na'eat the beginning of the selbri in both and , we get different results:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi na'e sutra cadzu be fi le birka be'o je masno klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I ( (non- quickly) – (walking using the arms) and slowly) go-to the market.
interlinear-gloss.en: I go to the market, both walking using my arms other than quickly, and also slowly.
interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi na'e ke sutra cadzu be fi le birka [be'o] ke'e je masno klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I (non-(quickly (walking using the arms) ) and slowly) go-to the market.
interlinear-gloss.en: I go to the market, both other than quickly walking using my arms, and also slowly.

section.para: The difference arises because the na'ein negates the whole construction from keto ke'e, whereas in it negates sutraalone.
Beware of omitting terminators in these complex examples! If the explicit ke'eis left out in , it is transformed into:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi na'e ke sutra cadzu be fi le birka be'o je masno klama [ke'e] le zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I non-(quickly ( (walking using the arms) ) and slowly) go-to) the market.
I do something other than quickly both going to the market walking
interlinear-gloss.en: using my arms and slowly going to the market.

section.para: And if both ke'eand be'oare omitted, the results are even sillier:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi na'e ke sutra cadzu be fi le birka je masno klama [be'o] [ke'e] le zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I non-(quickly walk on my (arm-type and slow) goers) on the market.
I do something other than quickly walking using the goers, both arm-type
interlinear-gloss.en: and slow, relative-to the market.

section.para: In , everything after beis a linked sumti, so the place structure is that of cadzu, whose x2 place is the surface walked upon. It is less than clear what an arm-type goermight be. Furthermore, since the x3 place has been occupied by the linked sumti, the le zarcifollowing the selbri falls into the nonexistent x4 place of cadzu. As a result, the whole example, though grammatical, is complete nonsense. (The bracketed Lojban words appear where a fluent Lojbanist would understand them to be implied.)
Finally, it is also possible to place na'ebefore a gu'e ... gilogically connected tanru construction. The meaning of this usage has not yet been firmly established.

section.title: 13. Tenses and bridi negation
section.para: A bridi can have cmavo associated with it which specify the time, place, or mode of action. For example, in

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi pu klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [past] go to-the market.
interlinear-gloss.en: I went to the market.

section.para: the cmavo puspecifies that the action of the speaker going to the market takes place in the past. Tenses are explained in full detail in . Tense is semantically a property of the entire bridi; however, the usual syntax for tenses attaches them at the front of the selbri, as in . There are alternative ways of expressing tense information as well. Modals, which are explained in , behave in the same way as tenses.

Similarly, a bridi may have the particle na(of selma'o NA) attached to the beginning of the selbri to negate the bridi. A negated bridi expresses what is false without saying anything about what is true. Do not confuse this usage with the scalar negation of . For example:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la djonz. na pamoi cusku
interlinear-gloss.gloss: Jones (Not!) is-the-first speaker
It is not true that Jones is the first speaker.
interlinear-gloss.en: Jones isn't the first speaker.

section.para: Various combinations of tense and bridi negation cmavo are permitted. If both are expressed, either order is permissible with no change in meaning:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi na pu klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: mi pu na klama le zarci
It is false that I went to the market.
interlinear-gloss.en: I didn't go to the market.

section.para: It is also possible to have more than one na, in which case pairs of nacmavo cancel out:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi na na klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: It is false that it is false that I go to the market.
interlinear-gloss.en: I go to the market.

section.para: It is even possible, though somewhat pointless, to have multiple nacmavo and tense cmavo mixed together, subject to the limitation that two adjacent tense cmavo will be understood as a compound tense, and must fit the grammar of tenses as explained in .

section.title: 14. Some types of asymmetrical tanru
section.para: This section and contain some example tanru classified into groups based on the type of relationship between the modifying seltau and the modified tertau. All the examples are paralleled by compounds actually observed in various natural languages. In the tables which follow, each group is preceded by a brief explanation of the relationship. The tables themselves contain a tanru, a literal gloss, an indication of the languages which exhibit a compound analogous to this tanru, and (for those tanru with no English parallel) a translation.
Here are the 3-letter abbreviations used for the various languages (it is presumed to be obvious whether a compound is found in English or not, so English is not explicitly noted):
section.programlisting: Aba = Abazin Kaz = Kazakh Chi = Chinese Kor = Korean Ewe = Ewe Mon = Mongolian Fin = Finnish Qab = Qabardian Geo = Georgian Que = Quechua Gua = Guarani Rus = Russian Hop = Hopi Skt = Sanskrit Hun = Hungarian Swe = Swedish Imb = Imbabura Quechua Tur = Turkish Kar = Karaitic Udm = Udmurt
section.para: Any lujvo or fu'ivla used in a group are glossed at the end of that group.

The tanru discussed in this section are asymmetrical tanru; that is, ones in which the order of the terms is fundamental to the meaning of the tanru. For example, junla dadysli, or clock pendulum, is the kind of pendulum used in a clock, whereas dadysli junla, or pendulum clock, is the kind of clock that employs a pendulum. Most tanru are asymmetrical in this sense. Symmetrical tanru are discussed in .
The tertau represents an action, and the seltau then represents the object of that action:
section.programlisting:
pinsi nunkilbra pencil sharpener (Hun) zgike nunctu music instruction (Hun) mirli nunkalte deer hunting (Hun) finpe nunkalte fish hunting (Tur,Kor,Udm,Aba = fishing) smacu terkavbu mousetrap (Tur,Kor,Hun,Udm,Aba) zdani turni house ruler (Kar = host) zerle'a nunte'a thief fear (Skt = fear of thieves) cevni zekri god crime (Skt = offense against the gods)
nunkilbra = sharpness-apparatus nunctu = event-of-teaching nunkalte = event-of-hunting terkavbu = trap zerle'a = crime-taker nunte'a = event-of-fearing
section.para: The tertau represents a set, and the seltau the type of the elements contained in that set:
section.programlisting:
zdani lijgri house row selci lamgri cell block karda mulgri card pack (Swe) rokci derxi stone heap (Swe) tadni girzu student group (Hun) remna girzu human-being group (Qab = group of people) cpumi'i lijgri tractor column (Qab) cevni jenmi god army (Skt) cevni prenu god folk (Skt)
lijgri = line-group lamgri = adjacent-group mulgri = complete-group cpumi'i = pull-machine
section.para: Conversely: the tertau is an element, and the seltau represents a set in which that element is contained. Implicitly, the meaning of the tertau is restricted from its usual general meaning to the specific meaning appropriate for elements in the given set. Note the opposition between zdani linjiin the previous group, and linji zdaniin this one, which shows why this kind of tanru is called asymmetrical.
section.programlisting: carvi dirgo raindrop (Tur,Kor,Hun,Udm,Aba) linji zdani row house
section.para: The seltau specifies an object and the tertau a component or detail of that object; the tanru as a whole refers to the detail, specifying that it is a detail of that whole and not some other.
section.programlisting:
junla dadysli clock pendulum (Hun) purdi vorme garden door (Qab) purdi bitmu garden wall (Que) moklu skapi mouth skin (Imb = lips) nazbi kevna nose hole (Imb = nostril) karce xislu automobile wheel (Chi) jipci pimlu chicken feather (Chi) vinji rebla airplane tail (Chi)
dadysli = hang-oscillator
section.para: Conversely: the seltau specifies a characteristic or important detail of the object described by the tertau; objects described by the tanru as a whole are differentiated from other similar objects by this detail.
section.programlisting:
pixra cukta picture book kerfa silka hair silk (Kar = velvet) plise tapla apple cake (Tur) dadysli junla pendulum clock (Hun)
dadysli = hang-oscillator
section.para: The tertau specifies a general class of object (a genus), and the seltau specifies a sub-class of that class (a species):
section.programlisting: ckunu tricu pine tree (Hun,Tur,Hop)
section.para: The tertau specifies an object of possession, and the seltau may specify the possessor (the possession may be intrinsic or otherwise). In English, these compounds have an explicit possessive element in them: lion's mane, child's foot, noble's cow.
section.programlisting:
cinfo kerfa lion mane (Kor,Tur,Hun,Udm,Qab) verba jamfu child foot (Swe) nixli tuple girl leg (Swe) cinfo jamfu lion foot (Que) danlu skapi animal skin (Ewe) ralju zdani chief house (Ewe) jmive munje living world (Skt) nobli bakni noble cow (Skt) nolraitru ralju king chief (Skt = emperor)
nolraitru = nobly-superlative-ruler
section.para: The tertau specifies a habitat, and the seltau specifies the inhabitant:
section.programlisting: lanzu tumla family land
section.para: The tertau specifies a causative agent, and the seltau specifies the effect of that cause:
section.programlisting:
kalselvi'i gapci tear gas (Hun) terbi'a jurme disease germ (Tur) fenki litki crazy liquid (Hop = whisky) pinca litki urine liquid (Hop = beer)
kalselvi'i = eye-excreted-thing terbi'a = disease
section.para: Conversely: the tertau specifies an effect, and the seltau specifies its cause.
section.programlisting: djacu barna water mark (Chi)
section.para: The tertau specifies an instrument, and the seltau specifies the purpose of that instrument:
section.programlisting:
taxfu dadgreku garment rack (Chi) tergu'i ti'otci lamp shade (Chi) xirma zdani horse house (Chi = stall) nuzba tanbo news board (Chi = bulletin board)
dadgreku = hang-frame tergu'i = source of illumination ti'otci = shadow-tool
section.para: More vaguely: the tertau specifies an instrument, and the seltau specifies the object of the purpose for which that instrument is used:
section.programlisting: cpina rokci pepper stone (Que = stone for grinding pepper) jamfu djacu foot water (Skt = water for washing the feet) grana mudri post wood (Skt = wood for making a post) moklu djacu mouth water (Hun = water for washing the mouth) lanme gerku sheep dog (dog for working sheep)
section.para: The tertau specifies a product from some source, and the seltau specifies the source of the product:
section.programlisting:
moklu djacu mouth water (Aba,Qab = saliva) ractu mapku rabbit hat (Rus) jipci sovda chicken egg (Chi) sikcurnu silka silkworm silk (Chi) mlatu kalci cat feces (Chi) bifce lakse bee wax (Chi = beeswax) cribe rectu bear meat (Tur,Kor,Hun,Udm,Aba) solxrula grasu sunflower oil (Tur,Kor,Hun,Udm,Aba) bifce jisra bee juice (Hop = honey) tatru litki breast liquid (Hop = milk) kanla djacu eye water (Kor = tear)
sikcurnu = silk-worm solxrula = solar-flower
section.para: Conversely: the tertau specifies the source of a product, and the seltau specifies the product:
section.programlisting:
silna jinto salt well (Chi) kolme terkakpa coal mine (Chi) ctile jinto oil well (Chi)
terkakpa = source of digging
section.para: The tertau specifies an object, and the seltau specifies the material from which the object is made. This case is especially interesting, because the referent of the tertau may normally be made from just one kind of material, which is then overridden in the tanru.
section.programlisting:
rokci cinfo stone lion snime nanmu snow man (Hun) kliti cipni clay bird blaci kanla glass eye (Hun) blaci kanla glass eye (Que = spectacles) solji sicni gold coin (Tur) solji junla gold watch (Tur,Kor,Hun) solji djine gold ring (Udm,Aba,Que) rokci zdani stone house (Imb) mudri zdani wood house (Ewe = wooden house) rokci bitmu stone wall (Ewe) solji carce gold chariot (Skt) mudri xarci wood weapon (Skt = wooden weapon) cmaro'i dargu pebble road (Chi) sudysrasu cutci straw shoe (Chi)
cmaro'i = small-rock sudysrasu = dry-grass
section.para: Note: the two senses of blaci kanlacan be discriminated as:
section.programlisting: blaci kanla bo tarmi glass (eye shape) = glass eye blaci kanla bo sidju glass (eye helper) = spectacles
section.para: The tertau specifies a typical object used to measure a quantity and the seltau specifies something measured. The tanru as a whole refers to a given quantity of the thing being measured. English does not have compounds of this form, as a rule.
section.programlisting:
tumla spisa land piece (Tur = piece of land) tcati kabri tea cup (Kor,Aba = cup of tea) nanba spisa bread piece (Kor = piece of bread) bukpu spisa cloth piece (Udm,Aba = piece of cloth) djacu calkyguzme water calabash (Ewe = calabash of water)
calkyguzme = shell-fruit, calabash
section.para: The tertau specifies an object with certain implicit properties, and the seltau overrides one of those implicit properties:
section.programlisting: kensa bloti spaceship bakni verba cattle child (Ewe = calf)
section.para: The seltau specifies a whole, and the tertau specifies a part which normally is associated with a different whole. The tanru then refers to a part of the seltau which stands in the same relationship to the whole seltau as the tertau stands to its typical whole.
section.programlisting: kosta degji coat finger (Hun = coat sleeve) denci genja tooth root (Imb) tricu stedu tree head (Imb = treetop)
section.para: The tertau specifies the producer of a certain product, and the seltau specifies the product. In this way, the tanru as a whole distinguishes its referents from other referents of the tertau which do not produce the product.
section.programlisting: silka curnu silkworm (Tur,Hun,Aba)
section.para: The tertau specifies an object, and the seltau specifies another object which has a characteristic property. The tanru as a whole refers to those referents of the tertau which possess the property.
section.programlisting:
sonci manti soldier ant ninmu bakni woman cattle (Imb = cow) mamta degji mother finger (Imb = thumb) cifnu degji baby finger (Imb = pinky) pacraistu zdani hell house (Skt) fagri dapma fire curse (Skt = curse destructive as fire)
pacraistu = evil-superlative-site
section.para: As a particular case (when the property is that of resemblance): the seltau specifies an object which the referent of the tanru resembles.
section.programlisting:
grutrceraso jbama cherry bomb solji kerfa gold hair (Hun = golden hair) kanla djacu eye water (Kar = spring) bakni rokci bull stone (Mon = boulder)
grutrceraso = fu'ivla for cherry based on Linnean name
section.para: The seltau specifies a place, and the tertau an object characteristically located in or at that place.
section.programlisting:
ckana boxfo bed sheet (Chi) mrostu mojysu'a tomb monument (Chi = tombstone) jubme tergusni table lamp (Chi) foldi smacu field mouse (Chi) briju ci'ajbu office desk (Chi) rirxe xirma river horse (Chi = hippopotamus) xamsi gerku sea dog (Chi = seal) cagyce'u zdani village house (Skt)
mrostu = dead-site mojysu'a = remember-structure ci'ajbu = write-table cagyce'u = farm-community
section.para: Specifically: the tertau is a place where the seltau is sold or made available to the public.
section.programlisting: cidja barja food bar (Chi = restaurant) cukta barja book bar (Chi = library)
section.para: The seltau specifies the locus of application of the tertau.
section.programlisting:
kanla velmikce eye medicine (Chi) jgalu grasu nail oil (Chi = nail polish) denci pesxu tooth paste (Chi)
velmikce = treatment used by doctor
section.para: The tertau specifies an implement used in the activity denoted by the seltau.
section.programlisting: me la pinpan. bolci Ping-Pong ball (Chi)
section.para: The tertau specifies a protective device against the undesirable features of the referent of the seltau.
section.programlisting:
carvi mapku rain cap (Chi) carvi taxfu rain garment (Chi = raincoat) vindu firgai poison mask (Chi = gas mask)
firgai = face-cover
section.para: The tertau specifies a container characteristically used to hold the referent of the seltau.
section.programlisting:
cukta vasru book vessel (Chi = satchel) vanju kabri wine cup (Chi) spatrkoka lanka coca basket (Que) rismi dakli rice bag (Ewe,Chi) tcati kabri tea cup (Chi) ladru botpi milk bottle (Chi) rismi patxu rice pot (Chi) festi lante trash can (Chi) bifce zdani bee house (Kor = beehive) cladakyxa'i zdani sword house (Kor = sheath) manti zdani ant nest (Gua = anthill)
spatrkoka = fu'ivla for coca cladakyxa'i = (long-knife)-weapon
section.para: The seltau specifies the characteristic time of the event specified by the tertau.
section.programlisting: vensa djedi spring day (Chi) crisa citsi summer season (Chi) cerni bumru morning fog (Chi) critu lunra autumn moon (Chi) dunra nicte winter night (Chi) nicte ckule night school (Chi)
section.para: The seltau specifies a source of energy for the referent of the tertau.
section.programlisting:
dikca tergusni electric lamp (Chi) ratni nejni atom energy (Chi) brife molki windmill (Tur,Kor,Hun,Udm,Aba)
tergusni = illumination-source
section.para: Finally, some tanru which don't fall into any of the above categories.
section.programlisting: ladru denci milk tooth (Tur,Hun,Udm,Qab) kanla denci eye tooth
section.para: It is clear that toothis being specified, and that milkand eyeact as modifiers. However, the relationship between ladruand denciis something like tooth which one has when one is drinking milk from one's mother, a relationship certainly present nowhere except in this particular concept. As for kanla denci, the relationship is not only not present on the surface, it is hardly possible to formulate it at all.

section.title: 15. Some types of symmetrical tanru
section.para: This section deals with symmetrical tanru, where order is not important. Many of these tanru can be expressed with a logical or non-logical connective between the components.

The tanru may refer to things which are correctly specified by both tanru components. Some of these instances may also be seen as asymmetrical tanru where the seltau specifies a material. The connective jeis appropriate:
section.programlisting:
cipnrstrigi pacru'i owl demon (Skt) nolraitru prije royal sage (Skt) remna nakni human-being male (Qab = man) remna fetsi human-being female (Qab = woman) sonci tolvri soldier coward (Que) panzi nanmu offspring man (Ewe = son) panzi ninmu offspring woman (Ewe = daughter) solji sicni gold coin (Tur) solji junla gold watch (Tur,Kor,Hun) solji djine gold ring (Udm,Aba,Que) rokci zdani stone house (Imb) mudri zdani wooden house (Ewe) rokci bitmu stone wall (Ewe) solji carce gold chariot (Skt) mudri xarci wooden weapon (Skt) zdani tcadu home town (Chi)
cipnrstrigi = fu'ivla for owl based on Linnean name pacru'i = evil-spirit tolvri = opposite-of-brave
section.para: The tanru may refer to all things which are specified by either of the tanru components. The connective jais appropriate:
section.programlisting:
nunji'a nunterji'a victory defeat (Skt = victory or defeat) donri nicte day night (Skt = day and night) lunra tarci moon stars (Skt = moon and stars) patfu mamta father mother (Imb,Kaz,Chi = parents) tuple birka leg arm (Kaz = extremity) nuncti nunpinxe eating drinking (Udm = cuisine) bersa tixnu son daughter (Chi = children)
nunji'a = event-of-winning nunterji'a = event-of-losing nuncti = event-of-eating nunpinxe = event-of-drinking
section.para: Alternatively, the tanru may refer to things which are specified by either of the tanru components or by some more inclusive class of things which the components typify:
section.programlisting: curnu jalra worm beetle (Mon = insect) jalra curnu beetle worm (Mon = insect) kabri palta cup plate (Kaz = crockery) jipci gunse hen goose (Qab = housefowl) xrula tricu flower tree (Chi = vegetation)
section.para: The tanru components specify crucial or typical parts of the referent of the tanru as a whole:
section.programlisting:
tumla vacri land air (Fin = world) moklu stedu mouth head (Aba = face) sudysrasu cunmi hay millet (Qab = agriculture) gugde ciste state system (Mon = politics) prenu so'imei people multitude (Mon = masses) djacu dertu water earth (Chi = climate)
sudysrasu = dry-grass so'imei = manysome

section.title: 16. Pretty little girls' school: forty ways to say it
section.para: The following examples show every possible grouping arrangement of melbi cmalu nixli ckuleusing boor ke ... ke'efor grouping and jeor jebofor logical connection. Most of these are definitely not plausible interpretations of the English phrase pretty little girls' school, especially those which describe something which is both a girl and a school.

Examples 4.2, 4.3, 4.4, 4.5, and 5.6 are repeated here as Examples 16.1, 16.9, 16.17, 16.25, and 16.33 respectively. The seven examples following each of these share the same grouping pattern, but differ in the presence or absence of jeat each possible site. Some of the examples have more than one Lojban version. In that case, they differ only in grouping mechanism, and are always equivalent in meaning.

The logical connective jeis associative: that is, A and (B and C)is the same as (A and B) and C. Therefore, some of the examples have the same meaning as others. In particular, 16.8, 16.16, 16.24, 16.32, and 16.40 all have the same meaning because all four brivla are logically connected and the grouping is simply irrelevant. Other equivalent forms are noted in the examples themselves. However, if jewere replaced by najaor joor most of the other logical connectives, the meanings would become distinct.

It must be emphasized that, because of the ambiguity of all tanru, the English translations are by no means definitive - they represent only one possible interpretation of the corresponding Lojban sentence.
